channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Putin Remains Defiant Toward West at Muted Victory Day Events
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin gave a televised address from Moscow’s Red Square ahead of a pared-back military parade, hours after Ukraine’s air defenses intercepted Russian cruise missiles headed for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Ex-Leader, Is Arrested
item.description: Mr. Khan, a former cricket star, has staged a comeback since being ousted, openly challenging the powerful military. His detention raises fears of mass protests.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood

item.title: Hong Kong Wants More Tourists, but Mostly ‘Good Quality’ Ones, Please
item.description: The return of budget tour groups from mainland China is sparking frustrations — and a dose of snobbery — in a city starved for business.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Olivia Wang
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mainland Chinese tourists at the Golden Bauhinia Square in Wan Chai district in Hong Kong, last month.

item.title: Israeli Airstrikes Kill at Least 13 in Gaza, Palestinians Say
item.description: At least three of the dead were leaders in Islamic Jihad, the group said. Officials reported that at least 10 civilians, including children, were killed in the strikes, which Israel said had hit the planners of attacks.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Raja Abdulrahim

item.title: In Turkey, Erdogan Loyalists Can’t Imagine Anyone Else in Charge
item.description: Staunch supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan still like his tough-guy rhetoric and critiques of the West and see no viable alternative, though he has been accused of mismanaging the economy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan hanging amid flags for his Justice and Development Party and the opposition Republican People’s Party in Kayseri, Turkey.

item.title: Capvision, a Consulting Firm, is Raided by Chinese Authorities
item.description: The consulting firm Capvision Partners is the latest to be raided in the name of national security, sending a chill through the foreign business community.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A surveillance camera in front of an office building, where the office of Capvision is located, in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.K. Protest Law in Spotlight as Police ‘Regret’ Some Coronation Arrests
item.description: The dozens of detentions around the crowning of King Charles III intensified a national debate about new legislation that broadens police powers to arrest and charge potential demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emma Bubola
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officers stopped and searched anti-monarchy demonstrators in London minutes before the royal procession began on Saturday.

item.title: Who Is Imran Khan and Why Was He Arrested?
item.description: The former prime minister, who was ousted last year, was arrested on corruptions charges.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Imran Khan, the former prime minister of Pakistan, speaking during an interview at his residence in Lahore in March.

item.title: Confusion in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Region as Russia Issues Evacuation Order
item.description: Running short of food, fuel and cash, and with a Ukrainian counteroffensive imminent, many civilians are defying a directive by occupation forces, unsure where they would go.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:description: In Enerhodar in Ukraine’s southern Zaporizhzhia region, in November.

item.title: China Retaliates After Canada Expels Diplomat Amid Influence Concerns
item.description: China ordered a Canadian diplomat in Shanghai to leave after Ottawa expelled a Chinese official who had been accused of gathering information on a Canadian lawmaker.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph and Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada speaking in March about a public inquiry into reports of Chinese interference in Canada’s election.

item.title: What Is Islamic Jihad and Why Is Israel Targeting It?
item.description: A brief guide to the armed group that saw three leaders killed in Israeli airstrikes early Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Islamic Jihad supporters at a rally for the 35th anniversary of the group’s foundation, in Gaza City in October.

item.title: George Berkeley’s Name Removed from Trinity College Dublin Library
item.description: No one disputes that George Berkeley was among Ireland’s greatest thinkers, but he was also an unapologetic slaver. Now, Trinity College Dublin is taking his name off one of its buildings.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: Trinity College Dublin has decided to rename its main library.

item.title: ‘Catastrophic’ Congo Flooding Kills More Than 400 People
item.description: Days after the flooding began, survivors are still pulling victims from the rubble and mud, and thousands have been left homeless. More rain is likely in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Members of the Red Cross continue searching houses for victims after the flooding in Nyamukubi, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, on Monday.

item.title: China’s Foreign Minister Meets U.S. Envoy and Urges Washington to Reflect
item.description: The meeting was one of the highest-level engagements between American and Chinese officials since the downing of a suspected Chinese spy balloon in February.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The American ambassador to China, Nicholas Burns. China’s foreign minister met with Mr. Burns and said he hoped the United States would “reflect deeply” on the freeze in ties.

item.title: Debt Limit: 4 Scenarios for What Could Come Next
item.description: Lawmakers are starting discussions on the debt limit, weeks before a critical deadline.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy.

item.title: What Is Russia’s May 9 Victory Day?
item.description: The holiday commemorating the Soviet defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945 is toned down this year as the war in Ukraine drags on.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Students in World War II-era costumes performing a Victory Waltz in Moscow on Saturday as part of the celebrations of the anniversary of the Soviet defeat of Nazi Germany.

item.title: LinkedIn Will Cut Over 700 Jobs Worldwide and Shut Its China App
item.description: Microsoft, LinkedIn’s owner, had already pulled the flagship networking site from China in 2021, leaving only a stripped-down app that catered to job seekers.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jiaming Center in Beijing, site of Linkedin’s China headquarters.

item.title: William Burns, a C.I.A. Spymaster With Unusual Powers
item.description: Mr. Burns, a key figure in bolstering the Biden administration’s support for Ukraine, has amassed influence beyond most previous spy chiefs.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: William J. Burns has for decades been a major actor on the American foreign policy stage. Now he has now amassed influence beyond most if not all previous C.I.A. directors.

item.title: Meet the Roving Veterinarians Caring for Mexico’s Rural Horses
item.description: Horses, donkeys and mules can be a lifeline for families living in the countryside, but there haven’t always been vets around to treat them.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Victor J. Blue
item.media:description: A veterinary student waits for a donkey to wake up from anesthesia at a clinic in rural Mexico.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A village along the front line in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region last month.

item.title: Battery Factories Are Driving Chinese Investment in Europe
item.description: Although China is investing less in Europe overall, Chinese battery producers are building factories to meet the demands of the region’s growing need for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: The Chinese battery maker CATL’s plant in Arnstadt, Germany, in January.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Texas Reels From Mass Shootings
item.description: Also, evacuation orders in occupied Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Cooper Neill for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered at a memorial outside the entrance to the Allen Premium Outlets in Allen, Texas, on Monday.

item.title: Wildfires Burn Nearly 1 Million Acres in Western Canada
item.description: Light rain and cooler temperatures brought much-needed relief over the weekend to Alberta, where nearly 30,000 residents have been forced to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: The Canadian province of Alberta declared a state of emergency on Saturday as more than 110 wildfires burned across it, but weather conditions were improving for firefighting efforts.

item.title: Russian Victory Day Celebrations Scaled Back
item.description: The Kremlin will commemorate the Soviet Union’s defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II, but many towns have canceled events on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Russian service members marching before a rehearsal for a Victory Day parade in Moscow on Sunday.

item.title: Berlin Attempts to Ban Russian Flags on Victory Day, Prompting Legal Tussle
item.description: Russian symbols will not be allowed at commemorations in Berlin marking the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany. Ukrainian flags will be permitted.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers at the Soviet War memorial in Berlin on Monday.

item.title: The New Surge at the Border
item.description: The new surge at the U.S.-Mexico border highlights a broader reality about immigration policy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Justin Hamel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants in El Paso last week.

item.title: Homemade, Cheap and Lethal, Attack Drones Are Vital to Ukraine
item.description: Fighting superior Russian firepower, Ukrainian forces turn off-the-shelf drones into deadly weapons by adapting them to carry explosives.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier, Yevhen, left, and his comrade, both from the Adam tactical group, fly their drones from a trench at a frontline position on the outskirts of Ivanivske, in eastern Ukraine in April.

item.title: Flamenco and Fervor: Inside Spain’s El Rocío Pilgrimage
item.description: The annual spectacle, featuring fanciful caravans and riders on horseback, is arguably the most potent visual representation of Andalusian culture.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Faingnaert and Anna Hart

item.title: At Least 22 Dead After Tourist Boat Capsizes in Southern India
item.description: Many victims of the tragedy in the state of Kerala were children who were sightseeing on a boat that officials said was overcrowded.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Rescuers searching for survivors after a boat capsized off the coastal town of Tanur in the Malappuram district of the southern state of Kerala, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Launched 35 Attack Drones Over Kyiv, Ukrainian Air Force says
item.description: Ukraine’s military said that it shot down all of the drones, in what was the fourth large-scale assault aimed at the city this month.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Russian drone attack in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Deaths of Seniors in Hospital Fire Point to China’s Elder Care Shortfall
item.description: The country’s supply of nursing home beds has not kept pace with its rapidly aging population, leading some families to seek unlicensed alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Police and security officers last month outside the Changfeng Hospital in Beijing.

item.title: Victory Day, the battle for Bakhmut, and NATO: What to watch for this week.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anushka Patil
item.media:description: A resident on Sunday in Siversk, a city in the Bakhmut region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Currents of change in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A couple walks towards Windsor castle during the Coronation Concert on Sunday.

item.title: Coronation and Election Leave Restless U.K. ‘in a Waiting Room’
item.description: Beneath the gilded continuity of the coronation celebrations, there were signs that both Britain and its royal family are preparing for a new era.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coronation of King Charles III on Saturday definitively turned the page from the 70-year reign of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Kishida Visits Seoul
item.description: Also, the U.S. braces for a surge of immigrants this week.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, left, and South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, at a news conference on Sunday at the presidential office in Seoul.

item.title: Arab League Votes to Readmit Syria, Ending a Nearly 12-Year Suspension
item.description: The country is poised for a triumphant return this month at the league’s next summit — perhaps represented by President Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian leader accused of committing war crimes against his own people.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Foreign ministers of the Arab League meeting on Sunday in Cairo.

item.title: Dutch Police Arrest 154 Soccer Fans Over Antisemitic Chants
item.description: Though the Netherlands’ Jewish population is tiny, Jewish identity — and antisemitic abuse — has become entangled in the country’s soccer culture.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: AZ players celebrating with supporters after a match between AZ Alkmaar and Ajax in September.

item.title: What It Takes to Be Top Dog Judge
item.description: For these canine experts, an invitation to pick the winners of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show is an honor — and a serious responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patricia Craige Trotter, judging Connor, an Old English sheepdog, during the 2021 Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. “What we’re doing is trying to achieve a level of near perfection in creating a working animal,” she said.

item.title: ‘The Glory’ Was a Hit. Now Netflix Is Spending More on K-Dramas.
item.description: As the series, which focuses on bullying and revenge, became the latest global sensation to emerge from South Korea, Netflix announced it would spend $2.5 billion more on Korean content.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Matt Stevens

item.title: How the Allen, Texas Mall Shooting Unfolded
item.description: A gunman killed at least eight people at a mall in Texas yesterday.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.media:description: Shoppers being evacuated from the mall.

item.title: Wagner Chief Appears to Backtrack on Threat to Pull Fighters From Bakhmut
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin said his mercenaries had been promised the ammunition and equipment they needed and would not have to withdraw from Russia’s fight for the eastern Ukrainian city.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the western outskirts of Bakhmut last month.

item.title: Ukrainians Return Home, Renewed and Resigned
item.description: More than 5.5 million people who left after the war began in February 2022 have gone back home — and not just to large cities like Kyiv or Dnipro, but to small places near the front line, as well.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers on a train from Lviv and Kyiv arrive in town of Pokrovsk in the eastern Donetsk region, last week.

item.title: Did China Help Vancouver’s Mayor Win Election?
item.description: Ken Sim, Vancouver’s first mayor of Chinese descent, rejects claims of Chinese interference and says his landslide win was due to his tireless campaigning and more appealing policies.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Ken Sim of Vancouver, British Columbia, in his office.

item.title: At Charles’s Coronation, Everything Olde Was New Again
item.description: The king promised a thoroughly 21st-century ceremony, but when push came to shove, he took his place on a 13th-century throne.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles arrived at Westminster Abbey from Buckingham Palace via horse-drawn coach. The king promised a modern coronation, but could not escape the burdens of the past.

item.title: The 2 Israels: Court Crisis Is Front Line for Dueling Visions of a Nation’s Future
item.description: For many Israelis, their country’s future rests on the fate of a government plan to overhaul the courts. In a remote part of northeastern Israel, ethnic and religious differences among Jews show why the issue has become so important.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Religious and secular people last month at the Amal river. Competing visions of what Israel is and should be are part of an existential battle that has divided the country for years.

item.title: ‘I See No Future’: Sherpas Leave the Job They Made Famous
item.description: Perils of the job and a scant safety net are pushing climbing guides to leave the industry and ensure the next generation has other options.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kami Rita Sherpa, a renowned mountain guide, encouraged his two children to pursue college degrees, which they are now completing.

item.title: The Forces Behind South Korea’s and Japan’s Thaw
item.description: Eras of grievances between the two countries are giving way under the pressure of global changes, and with help from a personal outreach approach by both leaders.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida with his wife, Yuko, and others visiting the National Cemetery in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: ​Leaders of Japan and South Korea Vow to Deepen Ties
item.description: As Japan’s prime minister failed to deliver a direct apology for the era of colonial rule, South Korea’s president urged his nation to focus on present problems, not history.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, left, and South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, at a news conference on Sunday at the presidential office in Seoul.

item.title: Charles Is Crowned King in Ancient Ceremony With Modern Twists
item.description: The coronation, the first since Queen Elizabeth II’s in 1953, was a royal spectacle of the kind that only Britain still stages.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Camilla, Queen Consort of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles leaving Westminster Abbey after his coronation.

item.title: As king, Charles inherits untold riches, and passes control of his own vast holdings to William.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.media:description: The Duchy of Cornwall, which owns sites like the landmark Oval cricket grounds, has a 130,000-acre real estate portfolio and generates millions of dollars a year in rent.

item.title: Queen Camilla Seems Lighter in Her New Role
item.description: The coronation was not just the moment Charles finally ascended to a role in wait for his whole life, but also the final act in the long rehabilitation of the former Camilla Parker Bowles.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: King Charles and Queen Camilla traveling from Westminster Abbey in the Gold State Coach.

item.title: London Police Arrest Dozens of Protesters on Day of Coronation
item.description: Prior to the coronation, the police had said that there would be little tolerance for disruptive protests. On the day itself, more than 50 people were arrested, most on offenses that appeared to be connected to protests.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The London police stopped and searched anti-monarchy demonstrators on the Mall in London, minutes before the Royal procession began on Saturday.

item.title: Jamaica Could Become a Republic in 2024. What Will That Look Like?
item.description: The Commonwealth country has scheduled a referendum in 2024 on whether to cut ties to the British monarchy, opening up a debate on how to reshape the society.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: A protest demanding an apology and reparations for slavery in Kingston, Jamaica, last year during a visit by King Charles III’s son Prince William, Prince of Wales, and his wife, Catherine, Princess of Wales.

item.title: Judith Miller, ‘Antiques Roadshow’ Mainstay, Is Dead at 71
item.description: Known for her many guidebooks, she helped determine what was trash and what was treasure on the BBC series that inspired the American show.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Michael Fein/Boston Herald, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Judith Miller in 2004. She was known to the British news media as the queen of collectibles, and her books were considered the bibles of the antiques and collecting world.

item.title: Were William and Kate Late to the Coronation?
item.description: The Prince and Princess of Wales arrived at Westminster Abbey after King Charles III, prompting speculation among the many journalists covering the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince William and Catherine, Princess of Wales, leaving after the coronation ceremony for King Charles III and Queen Camilla in London.

item.title: At the Coronation, Harry and William Find Themselves Rows Apart
item.description: The sons of King Charles III did not appear to interact during their father’s coronation.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince Harry, center, at Westminster Abbey on Saturday, when he had a less prominent role than other members of the royal family.

item.title: Serbia Reflects on Gun Ownership After Mass Shootings
item.description: Back-to-back massacres have forced the country, still in mourning, to grapple with its complicated and long gun tradition.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral on Saturday in a village south of Belgrade, Serbia, for some of the victims of a shooting days earlier.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Ethnic Clashes in India’s Manipur State
item.description: Violence erupted over a question of who gets to claim special tribal status.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A truck burns on Thursday in Imphal, the capital of Manipur state, where there have been days of violence between rival ethnic groups.

item.title: In Australia, He Was a ‘Great Father.’ Secretly, He Was an Escaped Convict.
item.description: New DNA evidence helped confirm that a man who went by John Damon and died in Australia in 2010 was actually William Leslie Arnold, a convicted killer and escaped inmate from Nebraska.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: What Happened at King Charles’s Coronation: Key Moments
item.description: The lavish ceremony for Britain’s first new reigning monarch in 70 years, was brimming with ancient traditions with a few modern touches.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla waved to the crowd from the balcony at Buckingham Palace, after the coronation, on Saturday.
